paper_abstract: Consider a system of two polynomial equations in two variables: where has degree and has monomials. We show that the system has only real solutions when it has a finite number of real solutions. This is the first polynomial bound for this problem. In particular, the bounds coming from the theory of fewnomials are exponential in , and count only non-degenerate solutions. More generally, we show that if the set of solutions is infinite, it still has at most connected components. By contrast, the following question seems to be open: if and have at most monomials, is the number of (non-degenerate) solutions polynomial in ? The authors' interest for these problems was sparked by connections between lower bounds in algebraic complexity theory and upper bounds on the number of real roots of "sparse like" polynomials.
paper_title: On the Intersection of a Sparse Curve and a Low-Degree Curve: A Polynomial Version of the Lost Theorem
